name: TheAtlantic
text: Although photographers took many pictures of people of color during the Great Depression, Sarah Boxer writes, the preeminent photographic record of the period left them out. https://t.co/3KhdAejc3n

name: TheAtlantic
text: The U.S. government has left a void in guidance about Thanksgiving this year. @jameshamblin clarifies why staying home is so important, as difficult as it may be: https://t.co/fLXLNGUkQD

text: "The lesson here is that the identitarian left must not labor under the impression that all Black and brown people share their sense of racism as an ultimate deal breaker," @JohnHMcWhorter writes: https://t.co/gEpbv70Q5v

name: TheAtlantic
text: When it comes to Queen Elizabeth II, “The Crown” tends to forgive easily. But in its sharp and splashy fourth season, the drama stops treating the monarch as a faultless heroine, writes @shirklesxp: https://t.co/dyJpQ8XWjO

text:

@TMclaughlin3 explores what that means for Joe Biden https://t.co/GOZOmXtToL

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @yayitsrob: NEW: There’s a new industrial alliance in Washington.

Tesla, Rivian, and Uber are joining forces with lithium companies, charging companies, and some of the country’s biggest utilities to form @zeta_2030.

Its goal: Make 100% of new vehicles EVs by 2030.

name: TheAtlantic
text: The recent backlash to the Kardashians shows how the coronavirus pandemic has—for now, at least—rendered their class of celebrities obsolete, @skornhaber writes: https://t.co/l9rfrJNK0r

name: TheAtlantic
text: New data from the federal government makes it clear: Hospitals are filling up, writes @alexismadrigal, and they are running out of the staff they need to take care of patients. https://t.co/6vz6cuX3wS

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If our condition is a kind of democratic collapse—an erosion of institutions, an implosion of civic trust, an explosion of lies—then there isn’t a politician who has stood against it more wholeheartedly and eloquently than Obama," George Packer writes: https://t.co/lf5wTkxQUP

name: TheAtlantic
text:
1/ Hospitals are filling up—and they are running out of the staff they need to take care of patients.
 
New reporting by @alexismadrigal quantifies the extent of the crisis: 22 percent of all American hospitals expect to face a staffing shortage. https://t.co/gFp10qlRkU https://t.co/3C4HaZ1jIq

name: TheAtlantic
text:
2/ COVID-19 puts pressure on hospitals in two ways. If staff members get sick or are exposed to the coronavirus, they have to stay home, reducing the labor supply. Second, more patients increase demand.
 
A surge of cases makes both factors worse. https://t.co/gFp10qlRkU https://t.co/NtuhyRPCS8

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/ “In eight states, the situation is particularly dire,” @alexismadrigal writes. More than 35 percent of hospitals in Arkansas, Missouri, North Dakota, New Mexico, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Virginia, and Wisconsin anticipate a staffing shortage this week. https://t.co/gFp10qlRkU

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ Desperate times have led to some desperate measures. Last week, North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum ordered that health-care workers who have COVID-19 but are asymptomatic can be sent back to work. Many nurses object to the practice, Madrigal reports. https://t.co/gFp10qlRkU

name: TheAtlantic
text:
5/ If infections are not brought under control, too many people will end up in beleaguered hospitals, and the standard of care will fall, Madrigal writes.
 
“Unless hospitalization trends change, more people will die, and die within sight of a vaccine.” https://t.co/gFp10qlRkU

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/6 To follow our continuing coverage of the coronavirus pandemic, subscribe to The Atlantic Daily: https://t.co/HS3NO7xbFA
